The strong prima facie case threshold means that the moving party must show that the claim is almost certain to succeed.[104]

The motions judge also observed that Kamal and Muhammad obviously owed fiduciary duties to KCT. They were both directors and very senior officers. However, the business of KCT came to an end when it was assigned into bankruptcy by the Receiver in October 2013. As of that time, all or substantially all of its assets had been sold. Kamal and Muhammad had resigned as directors and their employment had been terminated. Nonetheless, their fiduciary duties to KCT may have continued to some degree.[105]

Kanata submitted that Kamal and Muhammad should have told the Receiver of their plans to set up a competing business, and if they had done so the transaction captured in the APA would have “cratered”. If so, the motions judge noted there might be a remedy. However, the issue on the motion was the availability of an interlocutory injunction now, as opposed to at that time, rather than a claim for damages. Whatever might have happened at the time, it remained the case that shortly thereafter the APA closed, KCT was assigned into bankruptcy and it had ceased all business. The opportunity for KCT to negotiate a different deal could not be recreated now using the proposed interlocutory injunction.[106]

Kanata also alleged improper solicitation of customers and misuse of confidential information. The proposed injunction regarding customer solicitation may have been relevant to KCT in 2013, but a fiduciary duty regarding non-solicitation ordinarily only continues post-termination in order to give the company time to solidify its relationships with customers before the former employee begins competition. That purpose did not support the continuation of the fiduciary duties to KCT.[107]

Finally, with respect to confidential information, there was the possibility of a direct claim by Kanata for breach of confidence but it had not been pleaded. There was also the possibility of that given the sale of the intellectual property and goodwill, the fiduciary duty to protect confidential information formerly of KCT continued for a reasonable time post-closing and post-bankruptcy. However, the court did not find the requisite strong prima facie case of breach of such a fiduciary duty. There was some evidence, which was flatly denied, and it did not meet the required threshold.[108]

In Edgetch HVAC Services Ltd. v. Ubhi,[109] the plaintiffs sought an interim injunction restraining the defendants from competing against Edgetch and from soliciting clients and employees of Edgetch. The defendants fell into three categories. Jesse was a one-third owner of Edgetch. Jesse founded Edgetch with the plaintiffs Randy and Thomas. Edgetch was an authorized sales and service distributor for gas detection products manufactured by Honeywell. From 2008 to 2014, Edgetch was solely in Jesse's name, as Randy and Thomas continued to work at Honeywell. In January 2014, after Randy and Thomas were laid off from Honeywell, the three of them engaged in a corporate reorganization of Edgetch and executed a unanimous shareholder agreement. James and Extreme were independent contractors for Edgetch. The remaining defendants were former employees of Edgetch. The plaintiffs alleged that Jesse orchestrated the resignation of the former employees, the incorporation of Extreme and the possession and control of Edgetch's confidential information for the purpose of competing against Edgetch with Extreme.[110]

The plaintiffs' narrative was one of being the victim to Jesse's plan to direct the other defendants to use proprietary information to solicit clients and compete against Edgetch in a way that did not overtly offend his obligations as set out in the USA. Jesse's narrative was one of the victim as well. He stated that he was the victim of exclusion by the plaintiffs who purposely denied him his rights under the USA and were now relying on it to prevent him from earning a livelihood with his recently formed company. Jesse submitted that the plaintiffs could not seek to enforce the restrictive covenants in the USA, as the plaintiffs effectively repudiated the agreement and excluded him from the business improperly. The former employees' narrative was one of good, honest people with no choice but to leave Edgetch to join Extreme in order to earn a livelihood, given the stresses created by nepotism and racism at Edgetch.[111]

The motions judge was of the view that it was the plaintiffs' narrative that was supported and demonstrated by the evidentiary record. The motions judge did not accept that Jesse was a victim of exclusion by Randy and Thomas. The exclusion efforts were conduct reactive to Jesse's efforts to defeat Edgetch by soliciting its clients and competing against it with the assistance of former employees. The motions judge did not accept that the former employees left Edgetch en masse without notice or transition because of nepotism or racism. The timing of the resignations coincided too conveniently with Jesse's efforts to have the restrictive covenants in the USA waived, and none of the letters of resignation detailed nepotism or racism as the reason for leaving Edgetch. The former employees left to assist Jesse with his efforts to compete against Edgetch through Extreme. Finally, the motions judge did not accept that James decided to rebrand and expand his business around the same time that Jesse was negotiating a way out of his restrictive covenants and the former employees resigned without notice. The only conclusion that failed to defy common sense was that Jesse took intentional and covert steps to coordinate with James and Edgetch employees in order to compete with Edgetch through Extreme.[112]

The defendants argued that there were no proprietary marketing or business techniques that Edgetch used to solicit customers on the basis that Edgetch's start up and service reports contain information that was easily obtained directly from customers and was generally offered by customers, upon request, to any service providers, especially competitive service providers who requested it, as this facilitated customers' efforts to secure competitive quotes from different service providers before awarding the work. The motions judge disagreed with this submission. Edgetch recorded their clients' specific products, pricing and servicing requirements. This was information critical to the company, permitting it to know the clients' needs and when these needs must be addressed. It was not sufficient to say that the remaining shareholders could have called their clients to ask about products, pricing or when servicing was due. The defendant Neha had the database of all clients, which included all upcoming scheduling for servicing, and she would update the database every evening. The documentary evidence reflected the use of this information, including service reports, start-up reports and the excel service database to solicit business on behalf of Extreme. The documentary evidence reflected the use by the defendants of Edgetch's proprietary information to solicit Edgetch's clients and compete with its business. It put them in a position to harm the business of Edgetch as it gave them the opportunity to reach out and schedule the service required in accordance with the information retained.[113]

The motions judge observed that the cases focus on the result of the enforcement of the covenant when adopting the strong prima facie test. It is the result, interfering with an individual's ability to earn a livelihood that properly informs the analysis. In this case, the restrictive covenant was agreed to by shareholders of equal bargaining power in a commercial context and not by an employee as a condition of employment or in the context of a sale of business. The motions judge concluded nonetheless that the strong prima facie test still applied as the consequence remained consistent in that the shareholder was restricted in his ability to make a living. Therefore, the higher threshold of a strong prima facie case was applicable to the first branch of the RJR-MacDonald test.[114]

Jesse was the only defendant that was contractually prohibited from soliciting Edgetch's clients or employees. He was the president and director of Edgetch. Jesse breached the USA and his fiduciary duties as shareholder and director by soliciting clients and employees of Edgetch and using confidential information to compete directly against Edgetch. While the evidence remained in its early stages and there had been some reliance on hearsay, the plaintiffs established a strong prima facie case as against Jesse. This conclusion was reached in the context of reasonable restrictive covenants in the USA. The USA was a commercial contract amongst business partners of equal bargaining power bringing different and complimenting skills to the relationship. At the commencement of their relationship, the partners negotiated and agreed to the terms therein. It must be presumed that they did so with knowledge of the industry and in a manner that reasonably reflected the risks inherent in their business. The court ought not to impose its views on reasonableness years later upon the breakdown of the relationship, unless the contract was entered into unfairly or circumstances occurred in the interim that could not have been reasonably foreseen at the time of the contract. Further, the territorial scope was limited and did not extend to all territories within which Edgetch did business.[115]

None of the remaining defendants were contractually prohibited from soliciting Edgetch's clients or employees or prohibited from competing with Edgetch upon leaving the company. However, as they assisted Jesse in the breach of his fiduciary duties, they too were liable for the breach.[116]

The remaining defendants denied possessing or misusing any information belonging to Edgetch and submitted that the information at issue was neither confidential nor proprietary. The motions judge disagreed with this submission. The documentary evidence demonstrated a strong prima facie case that Neha, Arjun, Vic and Rovind misused confidential information for the benefit of Extreme. Aman, Vic and Micky resigned their positions without notice, in order to work for Extreme. James incorporated Extreme. Extreme's business was founded, at least in part, on the misuse of confidential information. By their very employment with Extreme, therefore, the former employees could be said to have misused confidential information for the benefit of a competitor. The plaintiffs established a strong prima facie case that the defendants misused confidential information.[117]

The plaintiff in FLS Transportation Services Inc. v. Charger Logistics Inc.[118] provided logistic and freight brokerage services. Its contracts with clients were generally short-term. As a result, the business between third party logistics companies and their clients is easily transferrable. The Defendant Spalding had worked in the trucking, logistics and transport industry for over 20 years. He had developed a good relationship with a significant number of clients which he brought with him when he was recruited to join FLS in 2009. He understood from the terms of his employment contract that he could take his own book of business with him if he left FLS. Spalding opened a branch office for FLS in Milton, Ontario in 2012. At the time of Spalding's departure, FLS Milton had eight employees, including three salespersons. FLS Milton generated annual revenue of about $300,000 to $400,000. On February 26, 2016, Spalding was told that FLS had been purchased by a private equity firm. Spalding understood from this conversation that the new owners would likely close FLS Milton in the near future and transfer those operations to their larger office in Oakville. Spalding had no interest in moving to the Oakville office. At that point, Spalding decided to look for other employment. On February 29, 2016, Spalding resigned from FLS. The Defendants Burchatzki, Russell, Natt, and Miehm also resigned on February 29, 2016. The Defendants McIntyre and Costa resigned on March 1, 2016. Prior to their resignation, the former employees held the following positions at FLS Milton: Spalding was the Senior Branch Director; Burchatzki and Russell were Sales Executives; Natt was a Customer Service Representative; Miehm was a Logistic Support Representative; McIntyre and Costa were Logistics Coordinators. The Former Employees were hired by the Defendant, Charger on March 1, 2016 to work at its office in Mississauga, Ontario. Since the resignation of the Former Employees, FLS had seen about a 90 percent decline in the number of orders placed by the clients serviced out of FLS Milton.[119]

FLS alleged that the Former Employees removed confidential information related to all aspects of its business and clients. FLS alleged that the Former Employees used that information to solicit business, on behalf of Charger, from FLS' clients. FLS sought an interim injunction pending the hearing of a motion for an interlocutory injunction.[120]

Where an employer seeks to place restrictions on a person's ability to engage in their chosen vocation and to earn a livelihood, then a strong prima facie case must be shown. In such cases, the moving party must show that its claim is almost certain to succeed. The strong prima facie standard applies regardless of whether the basis for the restriction on an employee is based on a contract or a common law cause of action such as breach of fiduciary duty or breach of confidence.[121]

FLS submitted that the Former Employees breached the restrictive covenants found in their employment contracts related to retaining and disclosing confidential information as well as soliciting employees and customers. FLS also submitted that the Former Employees were liable at common law for breach of fiduciary duty and breach of confidence. The reasonableness of the covenants was questionable. First, FLS, in earlier proceedings, stated that for this type of business there is no proprietary interest in customers nor is there “confidential information” entitled to protection given that its client lists, rates and related business information are almost entirely publicly available. The evidence of FLS' own executives in other proceedings undermined its position on this motion that the business information was confidential and proprietary. In any event, even if the covenants were found to be reasonable, evidence did not support a finding that there was a strong prima facie case that these covenants had been breached by the Former Employees.[122]
FLS had also not established a strong prima facie claim for breach of confidence given that the information did not possess the quality of confidence.[123]

In Maudore Minerals Ltd. v. Harbour Foundation,[124] Maudore brought a motion to enjoin Harbour Foundation and City Securities from voting their shares and from soliciting proxies on the grounds that Dr. Howard Carr, who was Harbour Foundation's and City Securities Limited's nominee as a director on the proposed board of directors, breached a confidentiality agreement signed by him while acting on behalf of Harbour Foundation and City Securities. Alternatively, Maudore sought an injunction on the basis that the defendants perpetrated a breach of confidence by misusing confidential information. The Harbour Foundation and City Securities Limited together owned 18.4% of the shares of Maudore, a Canadian mining corporation, and together were its single-largest shareholder. With the support of the second-largest shareholder, Harbour Foundation and City Securities nominated and planned to vote for a new slate of directors at the annual and special meeting of the shareholders. On either theory of liability, the alleged breach was that Harbour Foundation and City Securities were using confidential information to obtain proxies with the aim of replacing the current board of directors with a new board.

In 2011, Harbour began to have doubts about the competency of Maudore's management. Harbour asked Howard Carr, to investigate Maudore. Dr. Carr analyzed the publicly available documentation about Maudore. He also reviewed public documents on the geology of the Comtois gold project and about volcanogenic massive sulphide deposits in the area of the project. Dr. Carr reported to Harbour that there was a good prospect that Maudore Mineral's property did contain an economically-feasible gold deposit as had been reported, but that the company's management seemed to be functioning at a very low level technically. Harbour decided to send his son along with Dr. Carr to visit the Comtois gold project site on behalf of the Harbour Foundation to verify the accuracy of the public disclosures and to assess the competence of the current management. Harbour contacted Mr. Shorr and asked about the possibility of his son visiting the project. Harbour did not mention that Dr. Carr would accompany his son. There was no advance notice of plans to replace or displace the management team. There was no disclosure that the agenda would be to assess management, Maudore's business plan, and general matters. None of these threatening prospects was ever communicated to Maudore. After learning that Dr. Carr would be attending, Maudore protected itself with a confidentiality agreement.[125]

There was a great deal of technical information discussed by Doctors Jourdan and Carr. Dr. Carr appeared to be extraordinarily well prepared for the meeting, and his questioning was substantive, detailed, and not superficial. Dr. Jourdan provided detailed and elaborate answers. Dr. Carr was provided with drill core sections and associated sections as requested. Dr. Carr's evidence was that the tour resumed and the group went to one of Maudore's drill sites. Shortly thereafter, they returned to the core shed and viewed more sections, which are physical samples and also cross-sections, which are data sheets or charts of information derived from physical sources. Dr. Carr saw between 20 and 50 of the approximately 100 cross-sections. The cross-sections would have included data that had been assembled from information learned after the 43–101 Report. Some or all of the information from cross-sections may have been disclosed in press releases or public disclosure documents after the 43–101 Report or information that would be disclosed in future press releases.[126]

Dr. Carr reported on the visit to Mr. Harbour. Dr. Carr prepared an outline of the steps he would take if he became Maudore's CEO, which he called the “100 Day Action Plan.” He presented the plan to a committee of Maudore's board, formed to consider new nominees to Maudore's board and management. Maudore alleged that Dr. Carr prepared his action plan using confidential information acquired by his visit to the Comtois site. Harbour Foundation and City Securities issued their Dissident Proxy Circular, which included as an appendix the “100-day plan” that had been prepared by Dr. Carr.[127]

The court was of the view that Maudore must show a strong prima facie case because granting or refusing the injunction would be determinative of the underlying dispute that concerned the election of competing slates of directors. With a possibly viable claim for breach of confidence in play, Maudore must simply show a strong prima facie case that (1) the defendants received confidential information pursuant to the Confidentiality Agreement or in circumstances governed by the law of breach of confidence; and (2) they made an unauthorized use of the confidential information (be that unauthorized use a breach of contract or be it a breach of confidence). Maudore had shown a strong prima facie case that the defendants received confidential information from Maudore. However, Maudore had shown only a weak case that there was a misuse of the confidential information. It followed that Maudore's request for an interlocutory injunction should be dismissed.[128]

The court observed that a misuse of confidential information requires a use of confidential information. Two uses were identified. First, the confidential information was used to motivate or to give Harbour Foundation and City Securities the comfort it needed to undertake a proxy fight, which it did not need permission to do but apparently required some measure of self-confidence to undertake. Second, the confidential information was used to prepare the proxy fight material. However, the Court did not regard these two uses of the information obtained by Dr. Carr as showing a strong prima facie case of misuse of confidential information. The first alleged misuse of the information lacked substance because the information obtained from the site visit was no more than a motivational catalyst and it was difficult to say whether the motivation came from confidential information or from the fact that the confidential information was consistent with the extensive public information that Dr. Carr had ascertained. The second alleged misuse of the information to prepare the dissident proxy circular, lacked substance because Maudore could not actually identify confidential information in the dissent proxy circular. Both alleged misuses arguably fell within the expressly permitted uses of assisting Dr. Carr in his review of Maudore's properties and projects for Harbour Foundation and evaluating Maudore's properties and projects on behalf of Harbour Foundation. It was arguable that using the information for the purpose of deciding to exercise shareholder's rights was not a misuse of confidential information.[129]

The balance of convenience did not favour the granting of an injunction. Assuming a breach of confidence, it seems not to have genuinely perturbed Maudore's management and there was something to be said for the suggestion that the discomfort or inconvenience was not genuine but rather a cover for a tactical device in the proxy fight. The parties were to be left to win or lose the proxy fight on the merits.[130]

For the purposes of a motion for an interlocutory injunction, the court in GDI Solutions Inc. v. Walker[131] did not need to consider whether there was a strong prima facie case that the other named defendants were fiduciaries of GDL, as there was a strong prima facie case that Walker was a fiduciary of GDL and the other named defendants were impressed with fiduciary duties by joining Walker at Hudson in a competing business. The plaintiff GDL discovered that the defendant Walker, the individual from whom it purchased the GDL business, had, with several of his former subordinates and employees at GDL, joined a newly established direct competitor that was actively soliciting GDL clients. Walker had started the information technology business in 2003. GDL purchased the business, including its goodwill, technology, and book of business, from Walker in early 2010. As a condition of the purchase, Walker became general manager of GDL, and expressly covenanted not to compete with GDL, solicit or accept business from its clients, solicit or employ its employees, or misuse its confidential information during his employment and for a period thereafter. In June 2011, Walker was introduced to Evershed and Jankovic, a former employee of GDL. Evershed was planning to expand his IT business to Ottawa. He incorporated Hudson on October 24, 2011. Jankovic helped to set up Hudson. In November of 2011, Walker and Mears both left GDL. Walker advised GDL that he was going to do consulting work and Mears advised that he was going to work for his father, an IT consultant. Both joined Hudson. Hudson then began to offer a CPR-like service for data recovery. There were only two companies other than GDL and Hudson offering such a service. Other employees also joined Hudson.[132] There was no evidence that any of the defendants other than Walker had an employment agreement or a non-compete/non-solicitation agreement with the plaintiff. Fiduciary obligations attach to employees who depart with fiduciaries to work with competitive businesses. Were it otherwise, the fiduciary would be permitted to do indirectly what he or she cannot do directly. The plaintiff met the tests, that there was a strong prima facie case made out, that misappropriation of GDL's data and use of confidential information gave rise to the probability of irreparable harm and that the balance of convenience favoured the plaintiff in this regard.[133]

In Polar Wireless Corp. v. Roberts,[134] Polar alleged that four individual defendants had recently occupied key positions at Polar and had started competing directly with Polar through Go To. Polar also sought the return of any confidential and/or proprietary information of Polar by the defendants and an order preserving all information, documents and data in any format, electronic or otherwise, in the possession and or control of the defendants and relating to Polar, its technology, business and/or operations. The defendants did not have contractual non-competition agreements or non-solicitation agreements.[135]

The court noted that some courts in Ontario have held that the higher standard of a strong prima facie case should apply where parties are seeking to enforce restrictive covenants, both in the context of an employment agreement and the sale of a business. In other decisions, the courts have not insisted that the parties seeking to enforce a restrictive covenant make out a strong prima facie case. They have found that where a strong prima facie case can be made out, there is no need to examine the second and third parts of the injunction test. Where only a serious issue to be tried can be established, there is more emphasis on the second and third parts of the injunction test. Here, the court agreed with the approach of Justice Pattillo in Van Wagner Communications Co., Canada v. Penex Metropolis Ltd.,[136] that even if a strong prima facie case of a breach of a restrictive covenant by the defendants is evident, the issues of irreparable harm and balance of convenience must be examined, but may become less of a factor depending on the strength of the plaintiff's case.

Each of those respected judges are saying, in my view, that in the case of an interlocutory injunction to restrain a breach of a negative covenant, irreparable harm and the balance of convenience need to be still considered. The extent of the consideration, however, will be directly influenced by the strength of the plaintiff's case. Even where there is a clear breach of a negative covenant which is reasonable on its face, the issues of irreparable harm and balance of convenience cannot be ignored. They may, however, become less of a factor in reaching the final determination of the issue depending on the strength of the plaintiff's case.[137]

The motions judge concluded that there was a strong prima facie case that Roberts was a fiduciary and that those fiduciary duties had been breached by him and that there had been a breach of confidence by him. Roberts understood that after his termination he could advise his contacts of his termination and that was the extent of what he was permitted to do. He understood that he owed a fiduciary obligation to Polar. However, within 7 days of Roberts' departure, he was engaged in business on behalf of Go To and appeared to be soliciting Polar's business opportunities. There was also a strong prima facie case that the other defendants were impressed with fiduciary duties having joined Mr. Roberts at Go To which was a company that was clearly competing with Polar in the alternative roaming solutions industry. Fiduciary duties can apply to employee, and independent contractors, who leave with fiduciaries to work in a competing business. If the court were to grant injunctive relief, it must be granted against all of the defendants as their positions and responsibilities were essential to Polar's business and it appeared that they all had access to confidential information.[138]
